awd_titl_txt: Enumerative Geometry of Hitchin Systems and Topological Quantum Field Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research in mathematical physics. The topological and geometric structures of various kinds of spaces have captivated mathematicians and physicists for many years. The current proposal lies at the interface between algebra, geometry, combinatorics and analysis with applications to 2D-topological quantum field theory. In recent years the PI has organized several workshops that have specifically facilitated interactions between different research communities. The PI will continue to promote interactions between enumerative geometry, algebra and the theory of quantization in the direction emphasized in this project.


The proposed project is aimed at understanding a new point of view utilizing edge contraction operations of ribbon graphs. These operations were originally used to give a recursion relation of the generalized Catalan numbers of arbitrary genus. This recursion implies the DVV formula for the intersection numbers of tautological cotangent classes on the moduli space of stable pointed curves. The PI and a collaborator have discovered, an alternative axiomatic formulation for 2D-topological quantum field theory by edge contraction operations of ribbon graphs. The set of rules based on edge contractions also represent the key structure of topological recursion.  The edge contraction axioms reflect both the structure of a Frobenius algebra and the pair of pants decomposition of a topological surface. The pair of pants decomposition of a punctured Riemann surface was first used by Mirzakhani to give a recursion of Weil-Petersson volumes of the moduli space of hyperbolic surfaces with geodesic boundary components of fixed lengths. Using the multiplication and comultiplication of the Frobenius algebra we aim at giving alternative axiomatic definition of cohomological field theories in the same way. The goal of this project is to study the interplay between topological recursion, Mirzakhani recursion of Weil-Petersson volumes, the classification theorem of CohFT for semi-simple Frobenius algebra and character varieties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to study the interplay between topological recursion, ribbon graphs, Cohomological Field Theories (CohFT) for semi-simple Frobenius algebra, 2dimensional Topological Quantum Field Theory (2D TQFT), Mirzakhani's recursion of the Weil-Petersson volumes and character varieties.

Together with Motohico Mulase, the PI developed an equivalent axiomatic formulation of 2D TQFT whose formalism is based on the edge-contraction operations on cell graphs, ie graphs drawn on a Riemann surfaces. This formalism is based on pairs of pants decomposition of Riemann surfaces that is the main ingredient of the Topological Recursion formalism. Cell graphs are the Poincare dual of ribbon graphs used by Kontsevich. The main outcome of this project was the generalization of the classification result from the 2D TQFT  to CohFT. Namely the PI and her collaborator Motohico Mulase, developed an alternative functorial formulation for cohomological field theory CohFT discovering that the ribbon graphs and cell graphs duality provides a visual explanation for the Frobenius--Hopf duality and it gives a simple approach to the classification theorem for semi-simple Frobenius algebras. This new formulation gives a combinatorial approach to the Givental - Teleman classification theorem of Cohomological Field Theories for semi-simple Frobenius algebras via ribbon graphs. It is also a generalization of the classification theorem from 2D TQFT via ribbon graphs obtained by the PI and Mulase.

The PI is currently advising the graduate student Will Davis, who is working on extending results of 2D TQFT mentioned above to infinite dimensional Frobenius algebras. Will is also working on combinatorial problems such as the Catalan recursion of ribbon graphs, the twisted Catalan recursion by 2D TQFT, its interpretation in the topological recursion framework and quantum curves applications. Interesting results were achieved.

Intellectual Merit. During the grant period, 11 papers were accepted and published, (most of them in the area of enumerative geometry and quantization), and 6 papers were submitted. Influential published work of the PI and collaborators include papers as "Opers versus nonabelian Hodge" Journal of Differential Geometry 2021, "Interplay between opers, quantum curves, WKB analysis and Higgs bundles" SIGMA 17 2021, "Positivity of divisors on blown up projective spaces" I + II, Annali della Scuola Normale Superiore di Pisa and J. of Algebra. The published work also includes three lecture notes for students for eg. "An invitation to 2D TQFT and quantization of Hitchin spectral curves". Many of the PI's results from the above papers influenced young scientists and were further generalized by the leading experts. 

The PI was the Co-Editor of a 2021 Sigma Volume "Special Issue on Integrability, Geometry and Moduli in honor of Motohico Mulase" (together with G.Borot, S.Rayan and D.Zagier). This volume collects influential work of many authors in Mathematical Physics.

The PI co-organized two in-person programs in Mathematical Physics:  one conference in Max Planck Institute of Mathematics, Bonn 2019 and was the contact organizer of the BIRS workshop in Banff 2018. The PI promoted participation of women, graduate students and early career researchers and their interaction with leading scientists.

The PI organized a one year reading seminar in UNC for graduate students on Hitchin theory and Introduction to Gauge Theory (Fall 2021) and Kontsevich’s count of curves, Mirzakhani’s recursion, Witten-Kontsevich intersection numbers (Spring 2022). 

 

Broader Impact. 

Invited talks for dissemination of results.  During the 4 years period of the NSF grant, the PI honored over 30 invitations in international conferences and summer school programs, (most of them in-person), including 4 mini-courses for graduate students (3 hours long in IMSA Miami, SCGP, Tuebingen, Saskatchewan). Talk invitations honored include IHES, Steklov Mathematical Institute-Moscow, Canadian Math Society, Utah-Snowbird Resort, Simons Center for Geometry and Physics, IMSA-Miami etc.

 The PI was the academic advisor of the M.Sc student Robert Reed Hubbard that defended UNC in Spring 2022. Reed studied in his thesis the moduli of opers and Higgs bundles. After graduation, R.Hubbard accepted a position in the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics, one of the most advanced schools in our state.

The PI is currently the academic advisor of the Ph.D student William Davis  working on enumerative geometry of Catalan numbers and Frobenius algebras.

Between 2019-2020 the PI was the academic advisor of the CMU student Amer Rawashdeh, now Ph.D student Wayne State University, MI.

The PI is currently the temporary academic advisor for 2 UNC students and was part of 5 Ph.D defense committees in UNC, CMU and UC Davis (the graduate student Cooper Jacop). C.Jacob gave a generalization of the work of the PI and Mulase on Catalan numbers and topological recursion to bc-Motzkin numbers. 

 The PI considered that main objectives of my proposal were successfully achieved and presented in many conferences. They inspired young students and leading mathematicians and they gave rise to other projects in progress with graduate students.
